title-group.article-title: Natural Environment Disclosures in the Annual Reports of Chinese Listed Entities

abstract.p: This paper analyzes the level of natural environment disclosure (NED) in the year ending 2007 annual reports of Chinese-listed companies. Using a simplified NED index that accommodates a developing country setting, the results show a low level of NED. Only 2% of sampled companies make disclosures for all eight basic environmental issues in the NED index. Larger companies and resource companies disclose significantly more NED. Clearly there is scope for Chinese regulators and entities to improve the reporting of natural environmental issues. Strategies are explored to consider how NED might be improved.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Following the studies of Brown and colleagues (2004) and Brown (2007) analyses of natural environment disclosures in the Pacific Island Countries, this paper examines the level and predictors of natural environment disclosures (NED) in the annual reports of Chinese-listed entities for the year ending 2007. NED relates to environmental reporting, disclosing the impact of an entity’s activities on the environment and about the entity’s performance in managing these issues. Calls for additional NED abound from environmentalists, investors, financial analysts, accounting practitioners, the financial press, insurance companies, international multilateral organizations and academics (Rodrigue, 2010; Tilt, 2007; Unerman and Bennett, 2004).

It is an important study because little empirical research has been conducted on the environmental disclosure practices of Chinese companies listed on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges. Guo and colleagues (2007) note a gradual increase in the take-up by Chinese companies of natural environmental disclosures (Baskin, 2006) in a problematic natural environment (Liu, 2008).

Chinese economic growth and its material consequence, environmental pollution, are staggering. Western environmentalists have despaired at China’s voracious appetite for natural resources and the ensuing environmental damage. As the New York Times investigative series ‘Choking on Growth’ documents, the scale and the scope of China’s impact on the global environment are immense and tragic, whether measures in land, air, water, animals, or people. China has taken about two decades to pollute as much as the West has done from the Industrial Revolution in the 19th century to the present day. In just 20 years of economic growth, China has overtaken America as the world’s leading contributor of carbon emission, in large part because of its manufacturing prowess (Ziser and Sze, 2007: 393).

Indeed, Chow (2003) suggests China’s economic development (including the improvement of well-being, enhancement of civil liberties and free flow of information), and attendant environmental impacts, presents significant challenges for the world economy. While recent economic development will allow China to achieve the Millennium Development Goal of poverty reduction (Gaiha et al., 2009), it will also create even greater environmental degradation (Liu, 2008).

Perhaps the two most pervasive images or stereotypes of the Chinese economy are very impressive dynamism (e.g. the fastest rate of growth over the last two decades) and very horrendous levels of pollution. Most observers probably believe that this combination of the ‘good’ and the ‘ugly’ is far from coincidental. That is, China’s extremely rapid growth since the beginning of Deng Xiaoping’s economic reforms in the late 1970s is itself a primary cause of the nation’s disturbing environmental destruction, setting off processes which have exacerbated the considerable environmental disasters that occurred during the Mao era (Clark, 2002: 109).

Fang (2010) avers that China is attracted to the concept of being a low-carbon economy. This is manifested by the Chinese government’s target to reduce the intensity of carbon dioxide emissions per unit of GDP by 40 to 45% by 2020, compared with the levels of 2005. However, to achieve these targets, Fang (2010) notes that there needs to be changes to Chinese law and policy and improved development of technology. Currently there are no stand-alone Chinese accounting standards or international financial reporting standards that provide rules on Chinese natural environmental disclosures.
This study empirically assesses the extent of NED in the annual reports of Chinese companies, and addresses three research questions:

list-item.p: What level of NED is generated by Chinese-listed companies?
What factors help explain NED trends in China?
Are there differences between the NED rates of Chinese-listed companies and Port Moresby Stock Exchange (POMSoX) entities?

sec.title: The Importance of NED for Chinese Listed Companies
sec.p: As depicted in Table 1, there are a number of natural environment issues that touch upon Brown et al.’s (2004) NED index in a Chinese setting. NED comprises eight categories of general environmental conditions, environmental policy, environmental audit, environmental produce and process related, environmental financially-related data, sustainability, environmental aesthetics, and environmental other. The index itself was constructed for a developing country setting, in particular a Pacific Island Country milieu (Brown et al., 2004) where recent aggregate mean NED on the Port Moresby Stock Exchange (POMSoX) of Papua New Guinea was low (29%) (Brown, 2007). It is important, therefore, to consider how Chinese listed companies fare in the same disclosing NED index, particularly given both China’s and Papua New Guinea’s transitional emerging country status. Thus differences between the NED rates of Chinese-listed companies and POMSoX entities is conducted. Table 1 provides a brief explanation of the categories of NED and their application to Chinese-listed companies.

tr.td: A. General environmental conditions: General environmental conditions discloses an entity’s efforts in making statements about the pollution it may cause or curb, and may provide statements about an entity’s treatment of noise, air, water and visual quality; and statements about the capital, operating and research development measures to counter environmental pollution (Brown, 2007; Brown et al., 2004). Issues concerning general environmental conditions are particularly piquant given the recent high rates of economic growth and development (China Statistical Yearbook, 2007). In China there are 380,700 deaths per year caused by indoor air pollution and 275,600 deaths per year caused by outdoor pollution (World Health Organization [WHO], 2007a, 2007b). Air pollution levels in Chinese cities are among the highest in world (Clean Air Initiative for Asian Cities, 2006). Awareness of general pollution conditions has grown in China in recent times (Kolk et al., 2008; Liu, 2008; Welford, 2007a, 2007b).

B. Environmental policy: Environmental policy is an entity’s statement of its intentions and principles towards its overall environment, setting actions, aims and environmental targets (Brown, 2007). While considerable effort has been made at the centralized government level to invoke environmental policies, it is less clear whether listed Chinese companies have taken up this practice.

C. Environmental audit: Environmental audits check an entity’s environmental performance against stated objectives and environmental policies (Kolk et al., 2008; Watson and McKay, 2003; Welford, 2005). Environmental audits have been called for by both accounting professional groups (Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants [CICA], 1992; Federation des Experts Comptables Europeens [FEE], 1995; International Federation of Accountants [IFAC], 1995) and academics (Adamson and Shailer, 1998; Bebbington and Gray, 1992; Chiang and Lightbody, 2004; Dittenhofer, 1995; Jaggi and Zhao, 1996; Parker, 1996, 1997). Also, given the National Audit’s pledge to audit Chinese companies more comprehensively, there is much scope for the use of environmental audits.

D. Environmental produce and process related: This category emphasizes how phases for commercial projects develop energy-efficient environmental products and processes that address air, water and soil issues (Brown, 2007). Many commentators have commented on environmental produce and process-related matters of China (Frost, 2007), not always complementary (Hohn, 2008).

E. Environmental financially-related data: This category might pursue lower costs, increased investment and improved building capacity to fund environmental needs, such as environmental facilities and changes (Brown, 2007; Brown et al., 2004).

F. Sustainability: Sustainability discloses strategies that sustain the environment and produce profits for entities by satisfying the needs of the present without diminishing the ability of future generations to meet their needs (Brown, 2007). Sustainability often goes hand-in-hand with accountability and corporate governance (Kolk, 2008). Kolk et al. (2008) note that sustainability is sometimes equated with the ‘triple bottom line’ (Elkington, 1997). Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) announced its first sustainability guidelines in 1998 and its latest, the third version, in 2006 (Global Reporting Initiative [GRI], 2006). A considerable discourse has been made in China about tackling sustainability reporting issues (Peiyuan et al., 2007). The main drivers of sustainability reporting are maintaining enterprise image, supporting government policies, increasing enterprise management awareness and rising media pressure (Peiyuan et al., 2007). Chow (2003) suggests China’s sustainable development requires not just the existence of cheap labour, but also sufficient capital investment.

G. Environmental aesthetics: The philosophy of aesthetics experiences the world through human senses, and is especially concerned with the appreciation of particular things and objects when they strike the senses in an agreeable manner (Carlson and Berleant, 2004). Environmental Aesthetics brings together feeling and knowing through the core of aesthetic experience (Carlson and Berleant, 2004)

H. Environmental other: Environmental other is a residual category that captures any environmental issues not caught by the other seven categories (Brown, 2007). Note that the State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) of China does not have the authority to suspend proposed projects violating environmental laws and regulations or to remove officials for this noncompliance of those laws and regulations (Zhang, 2008). SEPA also lacks the authority to manage local environmental bureaus (Zhang, 2007). Fines under China’s current environmental laws are low and may only be imposed once (Zhang, 2007). Chinese environmental protection agencies at all levels of the governments are underfunded and inadequately staffed (Zhang, 2008).

sec.p: NED is important because it provides stakeholders information for key decision-making, although there are costs (Darrough and Stoughton, 1990; Verrecchia, 1990) and managerial constraints in disclosing (Deegan, 2006). The choice of eight items of NED is consistent with the past literature (Brown, 2007; Brown et al. 2004). As shown in Table 1, general environmental conditions inform stakeholders about an entity’s operations on environmental conditions. Environmental policy reveals an entity’s intentions and principles towards those conditions, environmental audit shows audit evidence of an entity’s environmental performance, environmental product and process related provides specific environmental information on an entity’s products and key processes and environmental financial uses calculative techniques to assess the entity’s environmental impacts. Table 1 also contains the categories environmental sustainability that discloses an entity’s strategy to sustain the environment, environmental aesthetics showing the entity’s sensual appreciation of its surroundings, and the residual category of environmental other.

sec.title: Determinants of Chinese Listed NED
sec.p: In examining the level and predictors of NED generated by Chinese-listed companies, and following Thomas’s (1991) contingency theory, this paper argues that a firm’s size, leverage, and profit represent three very important organizational attributes that may affect a listed company’s disclosure. In addition, this study avers that the size of the board of directors, percentage of independent directors on the board, top five shareholder concentration, ‘Big 4’ auditing status and dual listing on both the Chinese and Hong Kong stock markets are key factors of a listed company’s business environment that may also affect a Chinese-listed company’s disclosure. Domestic listing, small and medium enterprise (SME) status and industry type are also considered.

Thomas’ (1991) contingency theory is closely allied to stakeholder theory which recognizes that stakeholders have a right of account (Gray et al., 1997). Contingency theory explains natural environmental disclosure practices in terms of how entities respond to the demand of their business environment in which they interact and the control of that environment in order to survive. Although the theory is based on interactive propositions between entities and their business environment, there is generally a ‘lack of an explicit statement regarding the precise mathematical function of the implied interaction’ (Thomas, 1986: 257). Stakeholder theory takes up this interaction with the business environment, proposed by contingency theory, by identifying specific stakeholder groups in the business environment and explaining NED practices in terms of entity and stakeholder relationships (Henderson et al., 2004). There are two strains of stakeholder theory: one based on an empirical view of management where stakeholders are identified by the company according to the way each stakeholder furthers its interest and how they might be managed (Freeman, 1984); and the other based on a normative view, where all stakeholders’ interests are seen as important (Clarkson, 1995).
Figure 1 provides a conceptual schema outlining the testable hypotheses.

sec.title: Size (H1)
sec.p:
Past studies have found a positive relationship between entity size and the level of company disclosures (Ahmed and Courtis, 1999; Ahmed and Nicholls, 1994; Neu et al., 1998). Stakeholder theory argues that larger companies disclose more information to satisfy the needs of financial market stakeholders (Cooke, 1991) and avoid political visibility problems. A large company is likely to spend more money than a small company in communicating information (Alchian, 1969). Company accounting expenses are likely to reduce as a proportion of overall costs as company size increases, whereas smaller firms potentially face financial constraints in disclosing detailed accounts (Rahman et al., 2002). It should be noted that, in a developing country setting, size was not found to be a predictor of NED of Pacific Island Countries’ (PIC) entities (Brown et al., 2004) and Port Moresby Stock Exchange companies (POMSoX) (Brown, 2007), possibly because no one entity in the data-sets represented a very large organization. Both the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) and Shenzhen Stock Exchange (SZSE) are much larger stock exchanges that exist in the PIC. Thus the following hypothesis is raised
H1: There is a positive relationship between the level of company size and the level of NED of the Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Leverage (H2)
sec.p:
A common practice by companies is to borrow funds to pay for assets to generate income. The funds borrowed incur a debt. Company leverage is seen as the total debts incurred by a company divided by its total assets. Prior studies have also shown that leverage affects the level of disclosure both in a developing country (Barako et al., 2006) and transitional country setting (Gray et al., 2006). A highly-leveraged company is likely to disclose extensively to satisfy the needs of key financial lenders. Debt providers may be concerned about the assumed responsibility for environmental liabilities on liquidation of entities (Neu et al., 1998). Entities may seek to legitimize environmental performance through additional disclosure and thereby reduce the need for further scrutiny of its environmental risk profile. Malone and colleagues (1993) observed that leverage was influential in the extent of disclosure by oil and gas companies. As such, the following hypothesis is posed:
H2: There is a positive relationship between the level of company leverage and the level of NED of the Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Profitability Return on Assets (ROA) (H3)
sec.p:
Profitable companies are likely to release more information in their annual reports in order to present compelling reasons for management compensation (Cerf, 1961; Inchausti, 1997) and in order to maintain managers’ positions in a firm and their salaries (Owusu-Ansah, 1998). Wallace and Naser (1995) and Inchausti (1997) argue that return on assets (ROA) is an important proxy for profitability, a measurement of management accomplishment. With positive information (successful results) companies are likely to be more responsible to the stakeholders than those companies with negative information (sustained losses; Dye and Sridhar, 1995). A positive ROA demonstrates a firm’s efficiency and effectiveness (Owusu-Ansah, 1998). Companies with comparatively larger ROA are more likely to disclose detailed information in annual reports to justify financial performance and to reduce costs. Thus it is hypothesized that:
H3: There is a positive relationship between firms with larger profit and the level of NED of the Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Board of Directors (H4)
sec.p:
The importance of the board of directors is derived from its contribution to business prosperity, corporate governance and accountability (Yong and Guan, 2000). Corporate governance emphasizes the accountability and fiduciary duty of the directors towards their stakeholders (Easterbrook and Fischel, 1993). Sound mechanisms and guidelines have to be drafted and implemented to ensure effective and reliable management within the corporation and to protect the rights of the stakeholders (Balagescu et al., 2005). Sound corporate governance can make a significant contribution to the prevention of malpractice and fraud (Zingales et al., 2006). Yet there is an ongoing concern that in Asia corporate governance is more a matter of form over substance (Roche, 2005). The board of directors, which has the power to hire, fire, and compensate management teams, serves to resolve conflicts of interest among decision makers. The board of directors is perceived as an essential component of good corporate governance. Size of the board matters because larger boards are more likely to be associated with an increase in board diversity in terms of experience, gender, nationality and skills (Dalton and Dalton, 2005). Consistent with contingency theory’s emphasis on an entity’s business environment, inadequate disclosures on the natural environment by the CEO or inside directors may arise with smaller boards because there are relatively less board members to check information sets. It is argued that, as the number of directors increases, this power over information verification rises and as such the following hypothesis is posed:
H4: There is a positive relationship between the number of directors and the level of NED of Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Independent Directors (H5)
sec.p: As outlined in the previous hypothesis, in the context of corporate governance mechanisms, the board of directors is viewed as an important safeguard for problems arising from an entity’s operations (Strand, 2001). The existence of independent directors on the board of commissioners may help to prevent collusion among managers (Nam and Nam, 2004). It is thought likely that any conflict between disclosure and non-disclosure can be reduced by a greater level of independent directors.

Adams and Mehran (2003) suggest that increases in the proportion of outside directors on the board should increase a firm’s performance as they are more effective monitors of company managers. Therefore, the general expectation is that the more independent the board of directors, the greater the NED of the company. To test the degree of corporate governance as measured by independent directors, the following hypothesis is examined:
H5: There is a positive relationship between the level of independence of the directors and the level of NED of Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Ownership Concentration (Top Five Shareholder) (H6)
sec.p:
Shareholders (owners) of an entity have an important role to play in that entity’s operations (Sam, 2010). Some owners, by virtue of the size of their equity positions, effectively have some control over the companies they own (Villalonga and Amit, 2006). Berglof and Claessens (2004) note that, in cases where ownership concentration is held by a very few large shareholders, they have power to manage the majority of activities of their entity. Gilson (2007) argues that dominant shareholders are keen to maximize their wealth and operate in their own interests. Consequently the smaller-owners’ interests are brushed aside. La Porta and colleagues (2004) show problems associated with high ownership concentration. Thus, for example, under high ownership concentration, voluntary NED may be given less prominence than would otherwise occur if there was less ownership concentration. McKinsey and Company Inc. (2001) advises that distinct ownership structures should be scrutinized more explicitly. To formally test the impact of ownership concentration on NED, the following hypothesis is examined:
H6: There is a negative relationship between the level of ownership concentration and the level of NED of the Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Auditor Type (H7)
sec.p: Auditor type may have a bearing on NED. Large auditor firms may exert a monitoring role on reporting (Jensen and Meckling, 1976; Watts and Zimmerman, 1983). Larger auditor firms have incentives to maintain independence from client pressure to limit only certain financial information, because they have to protect their reputation (DeAngelo, 1981). The major auditor firms are thus more likely to encourage their clients to disclose a greater amount of information in published corporate reports (DeAngelo, 1981). Furthermore, larger auditor firms are less likely to be associated with clients that disclose lower levels of information in their corporate reports (Watts and Zimmerman, 1983).

While auditors generally have an important monitoring role (Tambulasi and Kayuni, 2007), the larger external auditor firms tend to make sure all material errors are made public and that client companies comply with the relevant regulatory and legal requirements (Owusu-Ansah, 2005). There are reasons for this preference: the major auditor firms have better technical skills, experience and expertise, and ‘Big 4’ auditor firms have an incentive to keep their reputation of high quality audits (Owusu-Ansah, 2005). Thus, on the basis of this position, it is hypothesized that:
H7: There is a positive relationship between firms audited by a ‘Big 4’ auditor firm and the level of NED of the Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Hong Kong Listed (H8)
sec.p:
Ortmann (2010) describes Hong Kong as a relatively free economy and administrative state, with much power resting in the bureaucracy. The link between Chinese-listed companies and the Hong Kong Stock Exchange has been considered by Li (2003) and Chow (2003). Jaggi and Zhao (1996) found Hong Kong managers considered environmental protection to be of importance for Hong Kong, but a review of environmental disclosures contained in annual reports indicates that there was a gap between perceived importance of environmental performance and actual environmental disclosures. We thus hypothesize:
H8: There is a positive relationship between firms dual listed on the Chinese and Hong Kong Stock Exchanges and the level of NED of the Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Stock Exchange Listing (H9 and H10)
sec.p:
It is possible disclosure rates will differ either between the SSE and SZSE or between companies listed on the small and medium enterprise board (hereinafter referred to as the SME Board) and those listed on the main board. We thus hypothesizes:
H9: There is a relationship between Chinese listing status and the level of NED of the Chinese-listed firms.
H10: There is a relationship between Chinese SME status and the level of NED of the Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Industry Category (H11)
sec.p: The application of NED might differ by industry type (Brown, 2007; Brown et al., 2004). Companies in certain industries may face problems in reporting effectively. For example, oil and gas industries might have difficulties in accounting and reporting for the complex area of oil and gas wells of exploration, depreciation, and depletion (Lin and Peasnell, 2000). Type of product line and diversity of product may cause companies to disclose differently (Redda, 2007). Specific industries have varying degrees of regulation due to their overall contribution to the national income of a country.

The characteristics of industries may reveal differences in reporting regulatory compliance (Ghose, 2006). Based on their economic position, creditors are able to insist on companies performing certain actions including the level of human resource information (Naser et al., 2006). Therefore, on the basis of this position, a non-directional hypothesis is proposed that:
H11: There is a relationship between industry categories and the level of NED of the Chinese-listed firms.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: For the purposes of determining the level and predictors of NED generated by Chinese-listed companies, annual reports were collected and analyzed from a total of 200 Chinese-listed companies, comprising companies from the SSE and SZSE.1 The SSE has a population of 1,562 listed companies (Shanghai Stock Exchange [SSE], 2011). A random sample of 100 listed companies was selected from the SEE (Shanghai Stock Exchange [SSE], 2010). A further 100 companies were sampled from the SZSE which has a population of 1,286 listed companies (Shenzhen Stock Exchange [SZSE], 2011). Of these 100 companies sampled from the SZSE, 50 companies were from the SME section and 50 were from the non-SME section. In other words, from the SZSE 100 randomly-selected companies were sampled such that 50 companies were from the SME section (Shenzhen Stock Exchange [SZSE], 2010). The 2007 annual reports of these 200 companies, representing the total sample, were examined for each of the eight disclosure issues (Table 1) and the NED score calculated as the number of issues disclosed in each annual report.

NED scores are acquired by companies through a disclosure index which is:
A quantitative based instrument designed to measure a series of items which, when the scores for the item are aggregated, gives a surrogate score indicative of the level of disclosure in the specific context for which the devise was created. (Coy et al., 1993: 122)

In the disclosure index, the contents of each annual report of the sample of companies are compared with the benchmark checklist and coded 1 or 0, depending upon whether or not the content conforms to the items listed on the checklist (Meek et al., 1995). The benchmark checklist is based on the checklist used in earlier studies, particularly based on reporting standards or guidelines, or discussions with practitioners and experts in the field (Hossain et al., 1995).The benchmark checklist used for the eight items of NED for this study was based on the NED checklist used in past studies (see Brown, 2007; Brown et al., 2004).

A disclosure index for every entity is calculated as the ratio of total score awarded to the entity divided by the number of times that are applicable to the entity. Disclosure indices may be classified into weighted or un-weighted indices (Cooke, 1991). In a weighted disclosure index, some disclosure items are given a higher weighting (score) than other disclosure items based on perceptions of importance (Cooke, 1991). An un-weighted index deems each component of the disclosure index as equally important and thus each item is awarded the same score when it is disclosed (Meek et al., 1995). The un-weighted index is the most often used in disclosure studies because it is considered more objective than a weighted technique, more relevant to all entities and avoids over-penalizing entities for non disclosure of items (Cooke, 1991; Chavent et al., 2006).

Values of independent variables were also collated from annual reports. These are defined in Figure 1, with values of leverage above 1 truncated to 1 and profit truncated at the 2.5 and 97.5 percentiles of −0.197 and 1.74 respectively to reduce the impact of outliers.

Descriptive statistics for the dependent variable NED, the independent variables, and regression analysis were performed in SPSS version 18.0. Regression analysis was performed with the general linear model, so the categorical variable industry was coded with three dummy variables distinguishing between the resource industry and each of the other three industries but statistical significance also reported for industry overall, using an F test (see Joseph and Taplin, 2011, equation 1). That is, companies in the manufacturing, real estate and services industries received a value of 1 for the corresponding three dummy variables respectively, and zero otherwise. Regression including all independent variables, and after backward eliminations, are presented as well as regressions using each of the independent variables separately.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 2 below depicts the number and percentage of companies disclosing each component of the NED index. Aggregated NED mean was a relatively low 42%. Only the items sustainability (mean of 88%) and environmental product and process related (60%) exceeded a mean of 50%. Six of the eight components had relatively low scores with environmental aesthetics (10%) and environmental audit (24%) recording the lowest scores. For the purposes of answering the research question about differences between the NED rates of Chinese-listed companies and POMSoX entities, the last column of Table 2 shows Port Moresby Stock Exchange companies’ NED scores for the year ending 2002 for comparison (Brown, 2007). Aggregated NED mean is noticeably higher by Chinese-listed companies than by POMSoX companies by 13%. However, POMSoX companies had three items that were higher than Chinese companies: general environmental conditions, environmental policy and environmental other.

fn.p: Of these 48 companies, 15 disclosed an audit by both government and an independent party, 22 by the government only and 11 by an independent party but not the government.

sec.p: The distribution of NED scores, as shown in Table 3, also shows some interesting patterns. Of the 200 companies sampled, only 2% disclosed all eight components of the NED index, with the mode being one out of eight components of NED. The mean NED equals 3.4 out of eight, or only 42% of the maximum disclosure.

fn.p: Note: Aggregated NED mean score is 3.4 out of the eight items, or 42%.

sec.p: Table 4 shows descriptive statistics for the independent variables. The number of companies from the four industries were four resource, 124 manufacturing, 54 service and six financial. There is significant evidence of differing mean disclosure scores for the four industries (p = 0.004, one-way analysis of variance [ANOVA]), 5.3 for resource, 3.2 for manufacturing, 3.1 for service and 3.8 for financial. Due to the small sample size of six financial companies, this significant result is driven by the higher disclosure by resource companies compared to manufacturing and service companies.

In Table 5 are the regression results when the NED index is the dependent variable. First, results are presented when each variable is considered as a sole independent variable (three dummy variables were constructed for the four industries). Size of company has the highest correlation with the natural environment disclosure score (r = 0.476, p < 0.001) while profitability (r = 0.172), size of the board of directors (r = 0.197), ‘Big 4’ auditor (r = 0.223) and Hong Kong listed (r = 0.225) are also significant (p < 0.05). Second, we present regression coefficients (B) and p-values from a multiple regression using all independent variables simultaneously and lastly the corresponding results from a backward elimination.

caption.p: Regression results for the NED index

fn.p: Note: *, ** and *** denote statistical significance at the 5%, 1% and 0.1% levels respectively.

Three dummy variables for industry were used in the regression; however, Table 5 reports the p-values comparing regressions with and without all three dummy variables simultaneously to assess the overall significance of industry. Table 6 reports the relationship between the NED index and industry.

sec.p: Size is highly significant (p < 0.001), with larger companies disclosing significantly more (a company with total assets 10 times larger is estimated to disclosure 1.7 more items on average) and, hence, H1 is accepted. More profitable companies are also more likely to make more disclosures (p = 0.037, Table 5) and this variable is the last to be removed during the backward elimination being moderately significant (p = 0.097) in the presence of size and industry.

Industry is also highly significant (p = 0.016) and, thus, H11 is accepted. Table 6 shows the levels of disclosure for each industry. First, the raw mean disclosure scores are presented, showing the resource companies disclosing significantly more than the other industries. Second, the estimated mean disclosure is presented after adjustment for size (so companies with the same size of 9.36, the mean size in the 200 companies, are compared). Although resource companies are still estimated to disclosure more than the other industries the difference is typically smaller because the fact that resource companies tend to be larger explains some of the differences in disclosure between industries. When comparing companies of the same size, resource industries have significantly higher disclosure than service (p = 0.011) and financial (p = 0.011) companies but only slightly higher disclosure than manufacturing companies (p = 0.099). Although financial companies have a relatively high raw disclosure compared to manufacturing and service companies, they are also significantly larger and after adjustment for size their disclosure is lowest.

fn.p: Raw means are average NED for each industry.
Size adjusted means compare companies with the same size of 9.36, the average size of sampled companies.

sec.p: Finally, larger companies were significantly (p < 0.001) more likely to make disclosures of all eight items in the disclosure index except for sustainability (p = 0.159). While most (88%, Table 2) companies disclosed sustainability it was not necessarily the smaller companies that failed to disclose this issue. In summary, whilst H1 and H11 were accepted, H2 to H10 were rejected.

sec.title: Conclusion and Summary
sec.p: The results of the study about the level and predictors of NED generated by Chinese-listed companies show that a relatively low level of NED is produced by Chinese-listed firms. Although Chinese-listed entities’ NED is greater than the very low levels of Port Moresby Stock Exchange entities, six out of eight categories of the NED index had disclosure rates below 50%. It appears the categories of general environmental conditions, environmental policy, environmental audit, environmental financial related data, environmental aesthetics and environmental other are given relatively short shrift by Chinese-listed companies. Despite numerous calls for environmental audits by both accounting professional groups and academics for decades (Table 1), only 24% of companies disclose such an audit. Approximately one-third of these companies disclosed audits by both government and an independent party; however, only approximately half of these companies disclosed a non-government audit. This raises relevant questions on the necessity of such an audit and who should conduct this audit.

The low level of disclosure (38%) for general environmental conditions is of particular concern. This issue relates to environmental pollution which is not only a subject of concern within China but also the rest of the world because of the threat of global warming. The majority of Chinese companies makes no mention of the pollution they generate or measures to counter environmental pollution. The focus on economic growth within China without even minimal concern for damage this causes the environmental surely cannot be maintained. This is an issue for all stakeholders and regulators, domestically and internationally. The International Accounting Standards Board, for example, needs to put in place strategies such as education, or even standards, to improve the practice of environmental disclosures.

NED scores for the components of environmental-product and process related and sustainability were relatively higher, suggesting that most Chinese companies are aware of the sustainability and product and process issues but less willing to dwell on environmentally-financial issues (for example, environmental financial related data and environmental audit) and environmentally non-financial issues (for example environmental policy and environmental aesthetics). Domestic regulators, such as SSE and SZSE, need to educate and regulate in this area to encourage Chinese-listed firms to disclose more.

Size (H1) and industry (H11) were found to be the major drivers of NED. The implication for regulators is that as a priority further education and regulation on NED should be focussed on smaller listed Chinese companies. Larger companies appear to make more NED in order to satisfy financial markets and avoid political visibility problems. They may also possess relatively larger amounts of resources to pay for the costs of voluntary disclosures. Contingency or stakeholder theory is unable to explain why some companies make higher natural environment disclosures than others because smaller companies and companies outside the resource industry make very low NED disclosures. An explanation for this is that Chinese society has focussed on economic growth rather than sustainability. This may need to change not only for the sake of environmental conditions within China but also because the threat of global warming is of importance internationally.

Consistent with the commentary by Fang (2010), there clearly needs to be considerable change in the regulations of environmental disclosure if China desires to be a low-carbon economy. Without changes to Chinese law and policy and improved development of environmental reporting, it appears unlikely that Chinese-listed companies will voluntarily generate more information.
